item.title: Game | Revenues with greater growth in more than a year
item.description:
Macao game recipes increased by 19 percent in June, compared to the same month of 2024, the biggest rise in annual terms since May last year. Last month, the territory casinos loved 21.1 billion patacas
The casinos raised almost 21.1 billion patacas in June in gross revenues, which represented an annual increase of 19 percent, according to data from the Directorate of Inspection and Coordination of Games (DICJ) revealed yesterday. The June results have represented the highest annual growth since May 2024 and followed the ascending trend, with last month to be the fifth consecutive with annual growth, after starting 2025 with a 5.6 percent falling fall in January. At the time, the break was explained by the circumstance that the Lunar New Year's tourist peak had this year later. The increase in casinos revenues also accelerated for the third consecutive month. This value was higher than that expected by Banco Citigroup, which had initially foreseen revenues of 19 billion patacas for the month, which would have meaning a homologous climb of 7.4 percent. On June 23, Citigroup analysts said, however, that it would not be a surprise if the value was higher, thanks to the concerts of Hong Kong musician Jacky Cheung, which began on June 20 and take place until July 5. Also JP Morgan Securities analysts said the casinos had benefited from two concerts in Macao on June 7 and 8 of the South Korean Pop star G-Dragon. The game sector has been having the best start of the year since 2019, before the COVID - 19 pandemic began. Between January and June, Macao casinos registered total revenues of 118.8 billion patacas, 4.4 percent than in the same period of 2024. This amount represents 79.4 percent of the accumulated in the first half of 2019. On June 12, Citigroup predicted that the game sector's revenues will grow 6 percent in the second quarter of 2025, closing the year with an increase of 4 percent to 235.7 billion patacas. Macao obtained in 2024 total game recipes of 226.8 billion patacas, 23.9 percent than in 2022, but only 73.2 percent of the registered in 2019, before the Covid-19 pandemic. It is recalled that the government predicted, in the initial budget for 2025, that the year would close with total revenues of 240 billion patacas, which would represent a 6 percent increase compared to last year. But on June 11, the Legislative Assembly approved a new budget, proposed by the executive, which reduces the forecast for public revenues by 4.56 billion. Secretary for Economics and Finance, Anton Tai Kin IP, admitted to the deputies that the cut is due to the fact that the game's gross gross revenues in the first trimester of 2025 "was" slightly below planned. item.title: Waste | Environmentalist calls for suspension of “ecological island”
item.description:
As Macao woke up to export to the interior residues of construction works, an environmentalist argues that the executive should give up the waste landfill project off the coloane beaches. Society vice president for the protection of Hong Kong dolphins highlights the importance of the area for the Chinese white dolphin habitat
The Government of Macao and the Ministry of Chinese Ecology and Environment signed an agreement to send to the other side of the border the inert materials that result from construction works, the Secretary's Office for Transport and Public Works revealed last week. The solution found for wide production of inert materials resulting from demolitions and constructions makes it necessary to land landfill landfill off the coast of Coloane's beaches, according to the company's vice president for the protection of Hong Kong dolphins, Viena Mak Hei Man. Speaking to the Cheng Pou newspaper, the environmentalist reiterated that the opinion that the so -called “ecological island” represents a threat to the stability of the natural habitat of Chinese white dolphins, a concern shared by other environmental protection activists such as Joe Chan. The fears of environmentalists are supported by studies by two Chinese universities, which in addition to the impact of large landfill also indicate maritime traffic to carry waste, and resulting pollution, as a risk factor for cetacean species. In addition, the landfill building process, which has a projected area of ​​almost a third of the mud, can endanger the life of this local dolphin species, which is on extinction. New life One of the studies commissioned by the Government of MSAR on the environmental impact of the so-called “Ecological Island”, prepared by Sun Yat-Sen University Academics, revealed that at least 144 Chinese white dolphins make the southern coast of Coloane their habitat. The results of the study were categorized as confidential, but were made public by the Macau channel of TDM in March last year. The academics highlighted the preservation of dolphins would already be complicated, even without the landfill landfill and volator ash, due to the level of pollution of the river estuary of the Pearls, which the study indicates as one of the most polluted in the country. As such, Viena Mak argues that the suspension of the project of the “Ecological Island” is urgent. However, the environmentalist applauds the waste transfer agreement, adding that the MSAR should consider waste treatment alternatives, as well as landfills and incineration, since more than 80 percent of macao construction materials are recyclable and can be transformed into aggregate materials for cement, asphalt and bricks. As such, Vienna Mak suggests that the MSAR executive reinforces cooperation with the interior of China to ensure that the materials sent are reused.

item.title: Elections | Caeal prevents information photographs that the law obliges to disclose
item.description:
Seng Ioi Man estimated that the final lists of the September 14 elections can be revealed between July 18 and July 31. Candidates are currently being evaluated by the State Security Defense Commission, which has exclusion powers
Although the electoral law requires postering in the public place of candidates for the elections of September 14, to be consulted by the population, the Commission of Electoral Affairs of the Legislative Assembly (Caeal) prohibited that information photographs are taken. The decision was justified by the chairman of the committee, Judge Seng Ioi Man, with the desire to prevent personal data from ending on the internet. According to the defined in the electoral law, after the candidacies are presented, Caeal has to affix the information at its headquarters. Part of this information includes the “complete identification of candidates and representatives”, composed of the name, date of birth, profession, naturalness, habitual residence, postal address and resident identity ticket number. However, and although the information is public, residents cannot take photographs of the affixed leaves. Speaking to journalists, Seng Ioi Man explained the option with the fact that Caeal intends to protect the personal data of candidates. "According to the electoral law, it is necessary to present the identity of the representatives and the candidates. It is necessary to affix all the information. But Caeal found that this information contains many personal data, and given the protection of the personal data of these individuals to CAEAL decided not to take photos," said Seng Ioi Man yesterday. Notices without penalties When Caeal was asked about the article of the law that allows to prevent photographs of public documents, it avoided specifying an article and asked journalists to consult the law. "You, if you need to read the law, can consult the law, because there are very detailed provisions," replied the president of Caeal. With the posting of the lists, warnings emerge to warn that people who disclose published data risk taking legal responsibilities and cannot take photographs. Nar away with the warnings is indicated the penalty corresponding to the disclosure of the information or taking photographs. “The law requires very complete, very detailed information, until the person's BIR number is disclosed, as well as the date of birth, […] after a prudent weighting, it was necessary to publish everything […] but we did not find it prudent to take photographs to safeguard the data of the lists in the lists. It didn't consider it prudent, ”he added. Evaluation lists Currently the lists presented are provisional and given that there were no complaints in the face of the information published by CAEAL about the members of the lists, the applications went to the State Security Defense Commission. The Commission makes the political assessment on the loyalty of candidates for MSAR. The opinion issued is binding to Caeal, and does not allow the appeal of the State Security Defense Commission. Given the procedural procedures of the elections, Seng Ioi Man explained that the decision of the committee should be known as late until July 15. As a result, at best the definitive lists will be confirmed on July 18. However, if there is an appeal for Caeal's decisions, for reasons other than those related to the decisions of the State Security Defense Commission, the disclosure of the final list can only take place on July 31.

item.title: WHO | Study reveals that one in six people in the world feels
item.description:
A World Health Organization report states that loneliness is a growing problem. Based on a study conducted between 2014 and 2023, the document concluded that one in six people in the world feel alone, with emphasis on young people from 13 to 29 years old. The Southeast Asian region has, however, less problematic values
More and more is spoken of the devastating impact of loneliness as a potentializing cause of diseases. This time, a report from the World Health Organization (WHO), released on Monday and carried out by the Social Connection Commission, brings data on the problem, concluding that one in six people say he feels alone, a state that is not synonymous with being alone. Moreover, the problem is greater in younger ones, because one in five says it feels alone, which shows that one fifth of the world's population between 13 and 29 years old says it feels loneliness. The study, entitled “From Solitude to Social Connection - tracing a path to healthier societies: WHO Commission on Social Connection Commission”, focuses on 2013 and 2024, thus encompassing the pandemic, a period when most of the world populations faced confinement periods, some of them alone in their dwellings. The study was sent to journalists from 194 WHO member countries, and the data were dealt with in line with other works already done on the subject and with the support of experts from around the world, including from China. Bin Yu, from the Medical College Tianjin University, was one of the project participants. The report points out that between 2014 and 2023 "it is estimated that 16 percent of people around the world-one in six-felt loneliness," something that "affects all ages and regions." However, it is a “more common feeling among adolescents and young adults”, with a rate of 20.9 percent of young people between 13 and 17 years old, while the rate reduces slightly to 17.4 percent in the case of young adults from 18 to 29 years. The feeling of loneliness "decreases with age", and is also "more common in low-income countries, where almost one in four people (24 percent) claimed to feel lonely." The WHO study also points out that “the highest rates are in the WHO African region”, with 24 percent; Following the regions of the Eastern Mediterranean (21 percent), and in Southeast Asia this feeling is less felt by respondents, registering only 18 percent. "The European region has the lowest rate, with about ten percent," says WHO, which distinguishes loneliness of social isolation. In this field, “data is more limited”, but the isolation of the elderly stands out. "Estimates suggest that 25-34 percent of the elderly are socially isolated," it is data on the years between 1990 and 2022. When it comes to adulthood, from 30 to 59 years, the percentage of people who feel only low to 15.1 percent, and in people 60 years or older, with 11.8 percent. Regarding gender, “estimated rates of loneliness in women and men are similar (16.1 and 15.4 percent, respectively), with the highest estimated differences between adolescents (24.3 percent between women and 17.2 percent between men) and the elderly (13 percent between women and 9.9 percent among men)”. Who else feels The report states that nowadays “social disconnection is widespread in all regions and in all age groups”, with consequences that are “serious and underestimated, affecting mortality, physical and mental health, well-being, education, economy and society in general”. "Its widespread occurrence and its serious consequences make it a serious issue of global public health," it is mentioned. And who feels more alone? The WHO highlights “marginalized groups”, namely “people with disabilities, lesbians, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer (or sometimes in question) and other individuals (LGBTIQ+) and migrants”. These people “are more likely to feel loneliness and isolation than other groups”, making it the caveat that “previous data are too limited to determine whether social isolation and solitude rates have increased or decreased”. In the case of disabled people, scenarios persist such as being unable to “access social facilities and take advantage of opportunities due to physical barriers in buildings, limited access to transportation and lack of affordable information and communication, while others face structural stigma that limits their job opportunities or other sociocultural barriers that lead to lower level of education, less stable relationships and more precarious housing conditions”. "Many factors" are identified that lead people to feel alone, namely "modernization, industrialization and technological changes", and may be "responsible for what, often, it is presumed to be an increase in social isolation and loneliness, but most remain without proof." "We know that certain factors increase the risk of individuals suffering from social disconnection. These include poor physical or mental health (especially depression), personality traits such as neuroticism, not having a partner or being single, living alone and characteristics of the built environment, such as poor access to public transport. The impact of digital technology is not yet clear, but experts recommend caution, especially to protect the mental health and well-being of young people." study. The WHO highlights, throughout the text, how it is difficult to quantify feelings of loneliness, being relatively recent this type of definitions and, above all, differentiation between the feeling of feeling alone and being effectively only. The report includes testimonies from people from various countries and cultures that describe that, even though they are with a partner or friends, they feel alone in a scenario caused by many factors. In the case of young people, "the finding of high loneliness rates between adolescents is consistent with the results of previous research, although the result may be subject to both developmental and methodological considerations." “As loneliness results from a perceived discrepancy between real and desired or expected social connections, the highest rate in adolescence can be due to higher expectations of social connections during the development phase, which is marked by significant emotional and psychological changes. The elderly report a comparatively greater satisfaction with their social relations. According to these estimates, the elderly have the lower rates of loneliness, the elderly. which contradicts previous studies that enhanced the elderly as the age range with some of the highest rates. This may be due to the limited availability and quality of the previous data on the elderly, ”is explained. The study highlights, however, that it is “possible that the prevalence of loneliness is greater among adults over 80 or older”, which is a “consistent conclusion with previous studies, in which there was a distribution in the form of 'U' of loneliness among older adults”. More than 800 thousand deaths We are in an era where so -called social health is at risk, being considered by WHO as "a vital but often neglected, health, as essential as physical and mental health." "Social relations can reduce the risk of disease, increase life expectancy and strengthen the fabric of communities and society. Social relations improve life, giving us meaning and a feeling of belonging," it is also read, and today loneliness affects one in six people around the world and causes "about 871,000 deaths annually (2014-2019)." "New estimates suggest that loneliness alone may be responsible for about 871,000 deaths a year. The economic cost of these comprehensive impacts on society is just starting to be understood. Estimates suggest substantial costs for employers, health systems and individuals. Stronger social connections provide important protection in health, social and economic domains," he reads. The report points out that many of these issues only now begin to be perceived and analyzed. "This has probably been happening for years, but the pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) and the growing concern for digital technology has brought more attention to the issue, including governments," he is explained. The WHO also points to a correlation between poverty or low income and the feeling of loneliness. "In general, the lower the performance group in a country, the higher the solitude rate. It is estimated that low-yielding countries have the higher (24.3 percent), followed by medium-low-yield countries (19.3 percent), medium-high performance countries (12.1 percent) and high-performance countries (10.6 percent)," he can be read. Despite some worrying scenarios, WHO leaves some suggestions and even says that "there is hope" to get around the problem. "There are effective strategies for promoting social connection and these must be expanded," for example, by the "regular monitoring of the prevalence of social connection, social isolation and solitude at the global, regional and national level." This monitoring should be viewed as "a high priority", allowing "to track progress and measure the impact of strategies to deal with the issue." It is also suggested the “international development and adoption of reliable measuring instruments, interculturally valid for social connection, social isolation and loneliness”, and as a priority ”should be viewed the creation“ of an instrument to measure social connection, as conceived in this report: in the three dimensions of structure, function and quality ”. The study was based on reference documents on global and regional estimates of the prevalence of loneliness and mortality due to loneliness, “the first of this type”; a global review of political documents; Network mapping and analysis, the inclusion of 64 experiences experienced by people in relation to social connection, social isolation and loneliness, as well as “high quality evidence, prioritizing systematic revisions, meta-analysis and large-scale multinational studies”, without forgetting the experience of the WHO technical advisory group itself, “composed of 20 renowned global experts”.

It is also mentioned that the show in question “presents a distinct group of renowned paint and paintings, displaying a variety of works that highlight various styles of ink and paint painting”, and all these women who collaborate with their works “use brush and paint as a means of expression, revealing their unique artistic qualities through the rhythm of the lines and the depth of paint, transmitting their thoughts and cultivation. artistic ”. Female charm The SCM and CAC hostel consider that it shows “not only shows the exceptional capabilities of female artists, but it also serves as an important platform for cultural exchange and artistic heritage”. In addition, during the exhibition, "the public will have the opportunity to closely appreciate the dedicated works created by these artists, experiencing their perseverance and search in the kingdom of art, while exploiting the unique artistic charm and the deep cultural richness of female artists." “We believe this exhibition will add a vibrant touch to Macau's cultural and artistic atmosphere, inspiring greater love and appreciation for ink and paint painting,” describes the organization. item.description: The Thailand Constitutional Court yesterday suspended the first minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra until the conclusion of a lawsuit, which began after the disclosure of a telephone call with a former Cambodian leader. According to a statement, the judges unanimously voted to accept a petition, presented by about 30 conservative senators who accuse Shinawatra of "serious ethical violation." In mid-June, a conversation with former Cambodian Prime Minister and current Senate President Hun Sen, in which Paetongtarn Shinawatra questioned the role of a high commander of the Thai army in the context of a border conflict between the two countries. The judges also approved for seven votes in favor and two against Shinawatra's suspension, which will be effective “until the [final] decision of the Constitutional Court”, which could take several weeks or even months, according to the statement. "I accept the court decision," the prime minister said yesterday to journalists, in front of the government palace in Bangcoque. "I want to reaffirm that it was always my intention to act in the best interest of my country," added Paetongtarn Shinawatra. Deputy Prime Minister Suriya Jungrungruangkit is expected to become the interim prime minister, although there is no official confirmation yet. Stability in question China yesterday expressed hope that Thailand will be able to maintain "stability" following the decision of the Constitutional Court. "As a neighbor friend, we hope Thailand will maintain its stability and development," said Mao Ning, spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs at a press conference. On June 24, King Maha Vajiralongkorn ratified a ministerial remodeling after the Bhumjaithai party abandoned the government coalition due to the so -called telephone. The remodeling resulted in the removal of the government of former deputy minister and interior minister Anutin Charvirakul, leader of Bhumjaithai. The next day, the party announced that it would present a motion of censorship against the prime minister in Parliament on July 3. Shinawatra also faces investigations over an alleged violation of ethics by the Thailand anti -corruption agency, whose decision can also lead to its dismissal. On Saturday, thousands of protesters joined the capital of Thailand to demand the resignation of the Prime Minister. About four thousand protesters, according to news agency France Press, filled the streets of banquecoque, shaking Thai flags and applauding speeches, interspersed with screams of indignation. Also yesterday, the judgment of Thaksin Shinawatra, former minister and father of Paetongtarn Shinawatra, accused of defaming the monarchy.

item.description: Wu Zhen (1280-1354), one of the "Four Masters of the Yuan Dynasty", lived in Jiaxing (Zhejiang) like many other literati disregarded by the bureaucracy of Mongol Dynasty, as it is in many of his paintings: isolated as a hermit on a fishing vessel "moving the rowing, thinking of the house where he wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, as he already wanted to go back, already You don't want to fish anymore. » One of his neighbor and painter named Sheng Mao (1313-1362), by Lin'an (current Hangzhou), who had moved to Jiaxing, living as a professional of this art, always had in mind the ideal of literate painters. In two paintings in the British museum that are attributed to him he is a servant in the middle of the forest, carrying a book in his hand (vertical roll, 99.6 x 29.2 cm) paint), in another a literate with his hands hidden by the cold walking in a snow-covered bridge towards a pavilion. The name given to the painting is: reading, alumiassed in the reflection of the snow. Together, the title and the two paintings seem to allude to a story referred to by Liu Yiqing (403-444) in Shishuo Xinyu, "new account of the legends of the world", about the historical figure of Sun Sheng (c.302-373) that from the most tender childhood to old age was always seen with a book in hand and so poor that at night, the reflection of the reflection of the winter. Moonlight over the snow to illuminate your reading. An example of persistence of the desire to know certainly appreciated by literati, but also remarkably by an Emperor of the Yuan Dynasty who reigned twice, named Tugh Temur (1304-1332) known as Wenzong. And that, being a foreign, cultivated the arts, customs and traditions. From their efforts to impose local culture on the Mongoral rulers, the creation of Kuizhang Ge would be highlighted in the spring of 1329, the “Star of Literature Pavilion Academy”, which among other activities such as the compilation of classical texts also appointed literati capable of recognizing, studying and commenting on works of art. Some were painters, like a literate from Zhejiang. Ke Jiusi (1290-1343) was one of those scholars (Boshi) of the Kuizhang Pavilion of which today can be read the comments on paintings and caligraffes of ancient masters such as Jing Hao (c.855-915) or Jiang Shen (c.1090-1138). In their own paintings, intuition in the composition of the landscape is notorious, which you see an example in the Mustard Garden Manual. Or in a vertical roll where two high -sided Bambus stems painted for the 'hidden virtue pavilion' (Qingbige, paper on paper, 58.5 x 132.8 cm at the Palace Museum in Beijing). In these two rods that grow along with solid stones and when climbing cross, and in which he applied the rigor of the discipline of handwriting, he will have mirrored the will of the court to follow the great lonely masters like Wu Zhen.

item.title: China-Portuguese | Chengdu Pavilion shows Portuguese products
item.description:
In the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion venture in Chengdu, pavilions for foreign countries and entrepreneurs who want to establish business in China are installed. Portugal is also there, represented by the Portugal Pavilion, but according to manager Ângelo Sousa, there is a lack of support from the Portuguese government and strength to combat competition
“For us there are no barriers between Portugal and China. We are 365 days here and there.” This is the way the objectives of the team that is behind the Portugal Pavilion present at the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion are presented in Chengdu and which is managed by two partners: Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa. The two realized that the Shanghai zone had reached a saturation point in the trade of products and that it was necessary to go more to the interior of the country to try to sell things as Portuguese as wine, cod or olive oil. HM talked to Yinhui Tui about this project on the fringes of a lunch in Lisbon by the Friends of the New Seda Route Association, chaired by Fernanda Ilhéu. The event served precisely for Yinhui Tui to present the objectives of the Portugal Pavilion and try to capture business interests. “This is a very important market for Portuguese products. In China we have separated the country [in commercial terms] in four markets. We have the region of Beijing and Shanghai, which we call 'Yangtze River Economic Zone', and 'Pearl River Economic Zone'. The fourth zone is composed by the cities of Chengdu and Chongqing and which is a new economic area established in 2020. Portuguese have a lot of potential in these markets, ”he said. The entrepreneur recalls that the marketing of Portuguese products is still below the one that is done by French, Spanish or other countries, but when the Chinese buyer discovers wine or olive oil, he is surprised. "In Shanghai, for example, some customers already have their opinion on French or Australians. But many think that Portuguese products have more quality," said Yinhui Tui, noting that in the area where the Portugal Pavilion operates in Sichuan province, "people are a little more conservative and prefer to try, prove and feel before buying." "Our pavilion is next to the French pavilion and we often see customers to opt for French wine. But when they go through our pavilion, they see our brands and ask what we have. When they realize that we have cheaper wine compared to French, they are surprised and say it is better, and then buy." This responsible explains that the population in the fourth economic zone is 130 million people, much more than the number of people living in the Iberian Peninsula. "Then I think it's a market with a lot of potential," he said. THE ROLE OF LUSOSINE Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa created Lusosino that it acts as the managing entity of the pavilion, which was born “with the intention of promoting Portuguese products in the Great Market of China”. Thus, there is a “showroom” of very Portuguese products, representing some brands known as is the case of Vieira crackers, Esporão wine, Sal Marnoto, the Prisca jams or Vista Alegre, among others. It is in this pavilion that "exhibitors display the best products, buyers discover trends and where they both find the conditions to realize business." Moreover, Lusosino, through this pavilion, helps Portuguese entrepreneurs in marketing campaigns and in the best way to contact potential Chinese customers. Specifically, Lusosino promises to perform “producer and brands records, commercial representation, market analysis, market support and preparation, among other services”, reads on the website. However, and according to Ângelo Freitas de Sousa to HM, there are many obstacles to putting Portuguese products in China. “[The Chengdu and Chongqing zone] has the advantage of being a growing market that is not overloaded with exporters and has no addictions as happens in the Shanghai zone. It is a very large market and where there are many producers.” By addictions, the entrepreneur refers to “competition” from other countries and buying habits of Chinese customers, who are faster looking for products from other nationalities than from Portugal. "There are habits of certain brands that are implemented and people don't even look at others or experience them." The Portuguese Pavilion project began with an idea of ​​Ângelo Ferreira de Sousa, who has a Chinese wife who helps him in the business. “I met Yinhui Tui, he liked Portuguese products, we were friends and then we ended up joining energy,” he said, explaining that the interior of the country is still knowing foreign products, not just Portuguese. "The Shanghai zone has nowhere to grow and this is a growing economic zone. There are many factories that are moving to Chengdu, so there will be more development," he said. Absence of marketing The Portuguese entrepreneur regrets that the Portuguese authorities have given little support to the project, except for any follow -up by AICEP - Agency for Investment and Foreign Trade of Portugal. "All the investment was made by us and we have not had a lot of support. We had some help from AICEP, but nothing special. We do fairs, the showrooms, to prove and know our products in major cities," said Angelo Ferreira de Sousa. The entrepreneur also regrets that, despite the list of hundreds of years between Portugal and China, there is still flaws in the commercial strategy for the export of Portuguese products in the country. "The Spaniards are much further ahead than us," he said. Regarding the role of Macao as a platform, the entrepreneur says it is equally difficult to bring products from Portugal to China or Macau to China, due to lack of customs agreements and little flexibility. "It is not because we call Macau that I can, for example, putting sausages, cod or preserves in China, or other Portuguese products. To pass from Portugal to Macau is easy, but it is no longer so easy to take after Portuguese products from Macau to China. We have not been able to do much through Macau, but we have not sought much," he said. At the presentation in Lisbon, Yinhui Tui advanced some figures behind the construction of the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion, and help to understand their size: about 70 billion euros of investment and a space of 300,000 cubic meters. The Portugal Pavilion does not only do contact sessions or fairs: if a businessman wants to leave tons of products there, he can do so. Then the pavilion is in charge of distribution through several areas of China. “In the southern market, closer to Macao, there is a lot of competition in some areas, so it should be betting inside China,” said Yinhui Tui, referring to the potential and factor novelty that exists in some areas of the country regarding commerce.

item.title: Coloane | Filipe Afonso launches work that highlights the importance of staff houses
item.description:
The latest book by Filipe Afonso, coordinator of the Architecture course at the University of São José, looks at a housing model at risk of disappearing, but can be seen in Coloane, or in old fishing zones of Hong Kong. “Coloane Grammar” presents alternative solutions for the reuse of these houses and their classification as a heritage
Taking the idea of ​​grammar that names the book, what are the main terms or concepts around Coloane, its tradition and preservation that can enumerate? The “grammar” of the book introduces the concept of vernacular architecture, which reflects the knowledge of the informal, local construction and the maritime identity of this Coloane community. It addresses the assets at risk, proposing a method of cataloging existing houses, this digital method, which establishes a dialogue between tradition and modernity to preserve this cultural landscape. What concrete proposals are suggested in the book for the protection and preservation of Coloane's stilts? The book proposes (indirectly) the classification of stilts as a heritage to give them legal protection. By cataloging existing stilts, the book contributes to preserving the memory of this type of architecture and a broader discussion about its possible protection. How could we reuse the stilts taking into account these specific ways of life and the economic diversification that the government wants to achieve? The stilts could be reused for experience tourism, or centers of cultural interpretation, valuing local history. They can be transformed into creative and artistic spaces or in fact propose new wood buildings along the water line, with various uses and that can generate value to the Coloane community, contributing to Macao's cultural and economic diversification. Why approach Coloane and the stilts? How did this project come about? Coloane and the stilts were approached by their architectural and cultural uniqueness, representing a threatened memory and identity of Macao. This assets at risk has a significant potential. The project also emerged from the gap of scientific knowledge about these structures and the urgent need for documentation, consolidating itself as an academic-scientific investigation. In the Asian or Southeast Asian context, are the coloane stilts or not unique in architectural terms? Water constructions are common in various Asian countries, Coloane's stilts are not a unique case in terms of existence. See the example, in Hong Kong, of the well-known Tai o village, but are unique in their specific context. Its architecture is the reflection of local regional influences and materials, adapted to the history of the evolution of Colona's fishing community and the development of Macao. Its value lies in its particular architectural language and its persistence in a rapidly transformed urban environment. What is the story behind the emergence of stilts? Are you associated with Coloane piracy reports, for example, which refer to the early twentieth century? The stilts emerged as a practical and functional solution to the sea -related way of life, allowing sea access, tidal protection and efficient use of space in coastal areas. Piracy reports in Coloane were not the direct cause of their emergence. Shapes are essentially the response of an informal architecture of local communities to adapt to the maritime environment. Museum Idea on Coloane Stop Stand since 2017 The need for preservation of coloane stilts is not a recent idea. Between 2017 and 2018, the Directorate of Tourism Services proposed the creation of a museum entirely dedicated to the stories of these dwellings arranged in Rua dos Navegantes, but the project was being postponed for legal reasons. In 2018, the Tribuna de Macao newspaper (JTM) published an article where it referred precisely the absence of “legal foundations” for the construction of new infrastructure in the Maritime area of ​​Macao, something that has changed, however, given that the MSAR passed, from 2018, to include in its jurisdiction the management of 85 square kilometers of maritime zones. Last year alone, the executive's plans for the creation of a “functional maritime zoning”, “maritime areas” and other related laws, and a concrete decision on what will be made on what will be made on the stilts. Both zoning and plan will be defined for a temporal period by 2040. One of the objectives of the executive is environmental and ecological preservation, as well as certain experiences of the population. One of the points of the public consultation report speaks of “optimizing ocean exploration modalities according to Macau's development needs; coordinating the use of sea in production, daily life of the population and ecology” and performing “intensive and economizers uses to realize the rational allocation of maritime resources”. In 2018, according to the JTM, STD assured that it would be necessary to “wait for the publication of the maritime area and administrative regulation on the administration of the use of maritime zones” and only then could you think of the planning of the museum. HM questioned STD of this article, and until the closing of this edition, obtained new clarifications. A gradual development In a master's dissertation in architecture, defended in 2023 at the University of Coimbra, Ana Rita Rodrigues made the study of the “Evolution of Macao Territory-Aterros and Urban Design in the Taipa and Coloane islands”, and concluded that “Portuguese occupation in the islands of Taipa and Coloane brought improvements in infrastructure, safety and village organization”. In the late nineteenth century, "there were already, in the islands, schools, hospitals and basic infrastructure, promoting the economic growth of the region." Referring to the existence of stilts “used for the construction of fishing and housing boats for fishermen, naturally facing the river”, in a coloane zone composed “by precarious housing of one or two floors, unlike the type of common housing found in mud or macao, which was more focused on high development”. The author also points out that “development was slower” in Coloane, as well as the absence, on both islands, of “a unified general plan and the need for better urban planning to ensure a cohesive and sustainable environment”.

item.title: Teaching | I was entering local schools, but resources are scarce
item.description:
The government has been betting on the introduction of artificial intelligence in territory schools, but with a few hours in the curriculum. In addition, schools complain of few resources to meet government goals
Macao schools have integrated artificial intelligence (AI) tools in classrooms, such as smart paintings and linguistic models, but some teachers warn that most are not prepared to comply with outlined policy for the sector. After classes, students at Pui Va Secondary School remain in the classroom, distracted to explore a smart condition. These staff - explains Ruan Zhan Teng, school teacher at the school - act as interactive projectors and are used as soon as the first year, to write, watch videos or participate in classes with digital media. "In the third year, students begin to learn to identify artificial intelligence in everyday life, basic programming and photos and videos generated by AI," the computer teacher added to Lusa. The change took place in 2024 and is stipulated in the law: AI should be included in primary education (with a workload of 17 hours and 20 minutes per year), from 7th to 9th grade (19 hours and 20 minutes) and from 10th to 12th (18 hours and 40 minutes). Despite the requirement, Andy Chun Wai Fan, professor and director of the University of Macao Information and Communication Center in Education, Note that schools face two obstacles: lack of resources and faculty formation. “Some schools have only one information technology teacher,” said Fan, also referring that institutions generally have computer classes only once a week. Do not update Pedro Lobo, a teacher in this area, with 30 years of experience in the territory, including at the Portuguese School of Macau, is concerned about the lack of training. "Most teachers are already a certain age, they have not grown with this new technology ... So the mindset is still short of all this evolution, and change is being so fast that it can hardly follow," explained the Portuguese. Education authorities require teachers 30 hours of annual IA training, however, Pedro Lobo considers not sufficient. Although this year has already studied almost 40 hours, the teacher says he is "little prepared". Regarding this government policy, Andy Chun Wai Fan also remembers that it is required to schools that address ethics, innovation and collaboration in the domain of AI, although it fits the institutions the creation of the manuals themselves. “We do not have a manual about what to teach (…), each school has its own ideas about what to do with its students,” wolf reacted, explaining that he teaches “transferring AI to school work”, either through image generation, small game development, AI ethics approach and copyright issues. Since 2021 at PUI VA In a different record, the Pui Va Secondary School, which introduced AI in 2021, assumes to be “well prepared” to “the change”. The institution spends about two million patacas a year on AI tools, employs seven information technology teachers (IT) and hired a university professor in Beijing to support. “We want students to be able to use artificial intelligence to identify problems and solve real -life problems,” noticed the IT Office Director of Chinese educational establishment, Chong Wai Yin. Here, students work, for example, with programming languages ​​(Python, Tencent, Iflytek), and AI models such as Deepseek and ChatgPT, engaging in intelligent city projects, in the first cycle, and in the creation of applications, at a later stage, said Zhao Qihao, former professor at the University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, who taught in Puija VA. “In the first cycle, we developed smart cities, automated houses and AI -powered parking systems (…). In the second cycle, students create mobile applications and sustainable technological projects,” he explained. In April, the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, LAM, announced that Macao's educational reforms for 2025 will focus on AI and include plans for an intelligent classroom in all schools. The Government of Macao attributed to the school network under the direction of the Directorate of Youth Education and Development Services (DSEDJ) 15 million PATACA for AI software for this academic year. In an email sent to Lusa, DSEDJ stated that the government “attributes great importance” to the teaching of information technologies. "The medium and long term plan for non-higher education (2021-2030) identified 'reinforcement of creativity and technological education' as one of the main directions of development," he explains in the note. However, Pedro Lobo questions the pressure on young students: "Are we seeing children 8, 9, 10 years old to develop applications? Maybe 1 percent is capable. The rest does the best they can. They have classes and homework that never end." Concerned deputies In the last debate of the Legislative Assembly, last Thursday, two deputies, Iau Teng Pio and Kou Kam Fai, linked to education, defended the need for “high quality development of education in Macao”, namely with the bet on AI. One of the suggestions, referred to during the interventions before the order of day, was the reinforcement of the “coordinated development mechanism between education, scientific and technological innovation and talents”, with the increase of “Stem resources [science, technology, engineering and mathematics] and artificial intelligence on basic education, rooting the basis of scientific literacy”. In the debate on the 11th of this month, it was up to Deputy Ma Io Fong to appeal to AI regulation to avoid scams, but also to increase the awareness of society in relation to this new reality. “With the rapid development of technology these days, the use of AI functions is gradually becoming important help for society and residents in daily life and work. However, AI can give rise to illicit acts, especially the worsening cyber attacks and the diffusion of false information.” Also during the period of interventions before the agenda, the deputy asked the executive to “reinforce sensitization and education on the prevention of AI fraud, to sensitize the elderly and young people, emphasizing that the dissemination of false videos generated by AI can be a legal offense with serious consequences”. In this context, the systematic integration of “AI safety knowledge in school curricula and the realization of different awareness and education activities with community associations was requested to increase public knowledge about AI technology and the risk derived for its abuse”. "It is also due, through cooperation between the government, society, schools and the family, to reinforce the ability to respond to information and the internet discourse, allowing to react, clarify and follow up on useful time, when the public faces information that can cause negative influences or be misleading," said Ma Io Fong in the 11th debate.

item.title: WHO | Study reveals that one in six people in the world feels
item.description:
A World Health Organization report states that loneliness is a growing problem. Based on a study conducted between 2014 and 2023, the document concluded that one in six people in the world feel alone, with emphasis on young people from 13 to 29 years old. The Southeast Asian region has, however, less problematic values
More and more is spoken of the devastating impact of loneliness as a potentializing cause of diseases. This time, a report from the World Health Organization (WHO), released on Monday and carried out by the Social Connection Commission, brings data on the problem, concluding that one in six people say he feels alone, a state that is not synonymous with being alone. Moreover, the problem is greater in younger ones, because one in five says it feels alone, which shows that one fifth of the world's population between 13 and 29 years old says it feels loneliness. The study, entitled “From Solitude to Social Connection - tracing a path to healthier societies: WHO Commission on Social Connection Commission”, focuses on 2013 and 2024, thus encompassing the pandemic, a period when most of the world populations faced confinement periods, some of them alone in their dwellings. The study was sent to journalists from 194 WHO member countries, and the data were dealt with in line with other works already done on the subject and with the support of experts from around the world, including from China. Bin Yu, from the Medical College Tianjin University, was one of the project participants. The report points out that between 2014 and 2023 "it is estimated that 16 percent of people around the world-one in six-felt loneliness," something that "affects all ages and regions." However, it is a “more common feeling among adolescents and young adults”, with a rate of 20.9 percent of young people between 13 and 17 years old, while the rate reduces slightly to 17.4 percent in the case of young adults from 18 to 29 years. The feeling of loneliness "decreases with age", and is also "more common in low-income countries, where almost one in four people (24 percent) claimed to feel lonely." The WHO study also points out that “the highest rates are in the WHO African region”, with 24 percent; Following the regions of the Eastern Mediterranean (21 percent), and in Southeast Asia this feeling is less felt by respondents, registering only 18 percent. "The European region has the lowest rate, with about ten percent," says WHO, which distinguishes loneliness of social isolation. In this field, “data is more limited”, but the isolation of the elderly stands out. "Estimates suggest that 25-34 percent of the elderly are socially isolated," it is data on the years between 1990 and 2022. When it comes to adulthood, from 30 to 59 years, the percentage of people who feel only low to 15.1 percent, and in people 60 years or older, with 11.8 percent. Regarding gender, “estimated rates of loneliness in women and men are similar (16.1 and 15.4 percent, respectively), with the highest estimated differences between adolescents (24.3 percent between women and 17.2 percent between men) and the elderly (13 percent between women and 9.9 percent among men)”. Who else feels The report states that nowadays “social disconnection is widespread in all regions and in all age groups”, with consequences that are “serious and underestimated, affecting mortality, physical and mental health, well-being, education, economy and society in general”. "Its widespread occurrence and its serious consequences make it a serious issue of global public health," it is mentioned. And who feels more alone? The WHO highlights “marginalized groups”, namely “people with disabilities, lesbians, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer (or sometimes in question) and other individuals (LGBTIQ+) and migrants”. These people “are more likely to feel loneliness and isolation than other groups”, making it the caveat that “previous data are too limited to determine whether social isolation and solitude rates have increased or decreased”. In the case of disabled people, scenarios persist such as being unable to “access social facilities and take advantage of opportunities due to physical barriers in buildings, limited access to transportation and lack of affordable information and communication, while others face structural stigma that limits their job opportunities or other sociocultural barriers that lead to lower level of education, less stable relationships and more precarious housing conditions”. "Many factors" are identified that lead people to feel alone, namely "modernization, industrialization and technological changes", and may be "responsible for what, often, it is presumed to be an increase in social isolation and loneliness, but most remain without proof." "We know that certain factors increase the risk of individuals suffering from social disconnection. These include poor physical or mental health (especially depression), personality traits such as neuroticism, not having a partner or being single, living alone and characteristics of the built environment, such as poor access to public transport. The impact of digital technology is not yet clear, but experts recommend caution, especially to protect the mental health and well-being of young people." study. The WHO highlights, throughout the text, how it is difficult to quantify feelings of loneliness, being relatively recent this type of definitions and, above all, differentiation between the feeling of feeling alone and being effectively only. The report includes testimonies from people from various countries and cultures that describe that, even though they are with a partner or friends, they feel alone in a scenario caused by many factors. In the case of young people, "the finding of high loneliness rates between adolescents is consistent with the results of previous research, although the result may be subject to both developmental and methodological considerations." “As loneliness results from a perceived discrepancy between real and desired or expected social connections, the highest rate in adolescence can be due to higher expectations of social connections during the development phase, which is marked by significant emotional and psychological changes. The elderly report a comparatively greater satisfaction with their social relations. According to these estimates, the elderly have the lower rates of loneliness, the elderly. which contradicts previous studies that enhanced the elderly as the age range with some of the highest rates. This may be due to the limited availability and quality of the previous data on the elderly, ”is explained. The study highlights, however, that it is “possible that the prevalence of loneliness is greater among adults over 80 or older”, which is a “consistent conclusion with previous studies, in which there was a distribution in the form of 'U' of loneliness among older adults”. More than 800 thousand deaths We are in an era where so -called social health is at risk, being considered by WHO as "a vital but often neglected, health, as essential as physical and mental health." "Social relations can reduce the risk of disease, increase life expectancy and strengthen the fabric of communities and society. Social relations improve life, giving us meaning and a feeling of belonging," it is also read, and today loneliness affects one in six people around the world and causes "about 871,000 deaths annually (2014-2019)." "New estimates suggest that loneliness alone may be responsible for about 871,000 deaths a year. The economic cost of these comprehensive impacts on society is just starting to be understood. Estimates suggest substantial costs for employers, health systems and individuals. Stronger social connections provide important protection in health, social and economic domains," he reads. The report points out that many of these issues only now begin to be perceived and analyzed. "This has probably been happening for years, but the pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) and the growing concern for digital technology has brought more attention to the issue, including governments," he is explained. The WHO also points to a correlation between poverty or low income and the feeling of loneliness. "In general, the lower the performance group in a country, the higher the solitude rate. It is estimated that low-yielding countries have the higher (24.3 percent), followed by medium-low-yield countries (19.3 percent), medium-high performance countries (12.1 percent) and high-performance countries (10.6 percent)," he can be read. Despite some worrying scenarios, WHO leaves some suggestions and even says that "there is hope" to get around the problem. "There are effective strategies for promoting social connection and these must be expanded," for example, by the "regular monitoring of the prevalence of social connection, social isolation and solitude at the global, regional and national level." This monitoring should be viewed as "a high priority", allowing "to track progress and measure the impact of strategies to deal with the issue." It is also suggested the “international development and adoption of reliable measuring instruments, interculturally valid for social connection, social isolation and loneliness”, and as a priority ”should be viewed the creation“ of an instrument to measure social connection, as conceived in this report: in the three dimensions of structure, function and quality ”. The study was based on reference documents on global and regional estimates of the prevalence of loneliness and mortality due to loneliness, “the first of this type”; a global review of political documents; Network mapping and analysis, the inclusion of 64 experiences experienced by people in relation to social connection, social isolation and loneliness, as well as “high quality evidence, prioritizing systematic revisions, meta-analysis and large-scale multinational studies”, without forgetting the experience of the WHO technical advisory group itself, “composed of 20 renowned global experts”.

item.title: History | The MA-chan escape to the colonial and macau
item.description:
The MA-chan family is from Mozambique with Chinese roots, sought its new path in the then colonial Portugal and since 1976 that set roots in Macao. José Manuel Machon, resident in the territory since he was 13, told Lusa the very peculiar trajectory of his family, which reflects many of the family directions taken in the years of war and the end of the Portuguese colonial empire
The MA-chan, the Mozambican family with roots in China, fled twice to communism and twice resumed in colonial Portugal. In 1976, they landed in Macao, where Mozambique's memory had erased with the departure of the Landins, African troops that parked in the territory for decades since 1912. According to a report by Luís Andrade de Sá published in Macau magazine in 1992, and quoted by the blog "Chronicles Macanese", the Landins were in Macao "for about five decades", and "the Chinese never used to their conviviality, suspiciously who had the huge blacks who played a horrible drumsticks while returning the ostensiva. ferocity ”. The term Landim became a reference “to identify all indigenous battalions that passed by Macau”, is described in the same report. Massá Ma-chan went in 1963 to the Namphlam, northern Mozambique Conservatory to register the fifth son, but once again denied this Chinese, with roots in Guangzhou, the transmission of the nickname to descent. José Manuel was the same as his brothers: the nickname Machon, corruption of MA-chan. The identity of José Manuel Machon, embryoly marked by this bureaucratic detail imposed by the then Portuguese Mozambique, is not only a reflection of the colonial past of Portugal, but from the beginnings of Sino-Mozambican relations. “I don't have great confusion, I tried to adapt to life,” he tells Lusa in Macau, where he has lived since he was 13. The grandfather-also MA-chan-was the one who defined that this story began in Africa, leaving China looking for better life, in the starter of the twentieth century, and settling in Nampula, alongside Sharing, a Macua woman, Mozambican ethnic group. Massá, the son -and father of José Manuel -was sent to Guangzhou at 14, to receive formal education there. When he returns to Mozambique, he is a married man with a bullet mark near his left shoulder. In China, he faced the Japanese in World War II and married a Chinese, which he met on the day of marriage, until, on the threshold of the civil war, which would victory to Mao Zedong's communists, fled. He dedicated himself to Nampula to the cucumber of the cucumber-the 'Magojojo'-and the tubar bit, which he exported to Hong Kong. The Great Return However, unable to adapt, the woman returned to Macao with her four children, where she died. Massá returned to marry, this time with a Mozambican - José Manuel came first, Carla later. When the Frelimo flag raised on the mast in Mozambique on June 25, 1975, the MA-chan-headed Macao, with a brief passage in Portugal, where they inhabited a pension paid by the then IARN. “We are nothing returned, because we have not returned anywhere, we are refugees,” says Carla Machon, residing in Portugal. “When my father heard again about communism, he fled,” says his brother, José Manuel. While speaking, bowling balls pack on the floor and travel the track to a new crash. The noise in the center of Bowling Future Bright does not seem to bother this big man, 61, fluent in Cantonese and Portuguese and president of Macao Bowling Club. “This is what keeps me stable. Instead of going to the glasses, I come here,” he notes. For Joseph, independence "it was an open openness, an opening to the world." It doesn't even talk about political reasons, but how important it was to cross half a world until you arrived in Macau. A new life In this page turn, the MA-chan/maachon family came to find, in 1976, a city with little civil presence abroad. José and Carla do not remember other Mozambicans, who began to arrive after independence, many from Portugal. Mong-Há's fortress is an old witness to Mozambique's presence in Macau. Then the Landins, Mozambican soldiers at the service of the Colonial Army were quartered, recalls journalist João Guedes, a scholar in the history of Macao. It is this historical circumstance that baptized the hill of Mong-há of “Mountain of Black Ghosts”. These troops, with the “greatest warrior instinct”, in the expression of Emperor Gungunhana, remained in Macao half a century, until around the 1960s. They were responsible, for example, by the storage of the siege gates, border of the territory with China and recurring incident place. “They passed by and faded as if they had never been,” resumes Guedes, indicating that there was no material heritage attesting this military presence. Not far from Mong-Há, but at the Riquexó restaurant, troops are still there, eternalized in photos hanging on the walls. This serves African chicken, macanese dish, whose origin is still today the target of debate. Two theories: It was created by the Portuguese chief Américo Ângelo, inspired by a trip to Mozambique. Another version realizes that, seeing the African soldiers missing roasted chicken, Americo made the dish. And the memory of macau-moca-mandamous relationships is not complete without evoking the trafficking in leaf. If, on the one hand, it is known that the Portuguese took slaves from the African colonies by settling in the doors of China, in reverse, were also sent via Macao, Chinese to work in Mozambique, often in slavery conditions. The sons were part of a migratory movement from the late nineteenth century, “to develop the Mozambican colony,” explains the professor at Joaquim Chissano University in Maputo, Fatima Papelo, who investigates Sino-Mozambican cooperation. The first group, he says, was sent in 1858 and "consisted of 30 men." More than a century later, in the struggle for Mozambican independence, Beijing supported the Liberation Front of Mozambique (Frelimo) and is one of the first countries to recognize the new sovereign state. In Macao, the reinforcement of the ties was later paid, with the transition from the territory of Portugal to China in 1999. But for José Manuel, Mozambique was always present. The last time it went, tells, visited and cleaned the family campaign, "there at Machamba". "It's a Chinese custom," he explained.

item.title: Elections | “Soldier of Mao” claims innocent and says he was six days unable to take a shower
item.description:
Accused of electoral corruption and having an illegal Mahjong business, Wong Wai Man yesterday returned to the load to cry out his innocence. The president of the Iron and Steel Shipowners Association says he was “provoked” to climb to the roof where he was a few hours, and was six days without being able to bathe or change clothes
The panorama of the legislative elections for the hemicycle already boils. In addition to these are the elections with the smallest number of candidate lists since the creation of the MSAR, the controversy is installed with the almost candidate Wong Wai Man, who tried to submit his candidacy without success. Also known as the “Soldier of Mao” and “Captain of Macao”, and after being accused of electoral corruption and having an illegal Mahjong business, behold Wong Wai Man yesterday returned to explanations: refuses the accusations that he is targeted, says he was persecuted by the authorities and refers to “torture” how it was dealt with. The president of the Iron and Steel Association was on Monday, several hours on a roof of a house made with a metal plate in the mud, having been rescued by the Fire Department. A solution that says it was “provoked” after being detained by the Judiciary Police (PJ), referred to the Public Prosecution Service and receiving the Commissioner's Call against Corruption (CCAC), which accuses him of having the illegal business. Wong Wai Man explained that, shortly after leaving the CCAC Office in the Nape area, he was intercepted by an employee of this body that alleged the lack of signature in some documents. However, not satisfied with the situation, Wong Wai Man picked up a taxi towards the mud, eventually taking refuge on the roof. "I had no other option, CCAC wanted to chase me to death. So I was on the roof," he explained. Regarding accusations of electoral corruption, man says he is poor and is unable to commit such illegalities. Regarding Mahjong's alleged illegal business, Wong Wai Man stressed that the Association's headquarters in fact has Mahjong tables, but only for the enjoyment of the partners. Regarding the use of money in these games, Wong Wai Man said there was always a sign to say that it was forbidden to be bets on money and that there was, at the association's headquarters, a box for donations, but that was intended for voluntary support of the members to help the association's operation. This is because, according to this, besides being president is also the only one to support all expenses of the Association of Iron and Steel shipowners, namely those related to income, water and light, considering that since 2014 that the entity has not received subsidies. One thing is certain: the association's headquarters will close doors tomorrow due to the end of the lease. Wong Wai Man says that for now, he will not look for a new address for the association because, for now, he has a more pressing subject: looking for a place to live. Wong Wai Man made the association's headquarters to his home. Life lesson Despite having missed the opportunity to submit a list and be a candidate for elections for the Legislative Assembly by Via Direct, Wong Wai Man argued that the most important thing was to participate in the whole process and learn new things. The "captain of Macao" also said that he is dedicated to society of heart and not by selfishness. Your ideal is to do things justly for society, since it argues that traditional associations do not defend the people. Wong Wai Man also told journalists a personal episode to justify their participation in social and public causes. "In 2007 my wife was pregnant and the hospitals convinced her to end the pregnancy because the baby's survival rate would be 50 percent, due to the fact that a fetal anomaly was detected after the exams. I insisted and the government eventually paid the operation worth 70 thousand patacas. So I want to make my contribution to return a favor" to heaven "," he said. Six days without bathing According to the All About Macau newspaper, Wong Wai Man reported that he was still six days without bathing and sleeping, having remained a week missing until he performed with CCAC this Monday. Before he did, he said he was a total of six days detained, which for himself was “torture”, and that in total was all this time without bathing, sleeping or changing clothes. On Sunday, you will have been able to go home. “Last night [Tuesday] I was finally able to sleep well and shower. I was six days without being able to bathe or change my clothes,” he explained. The climb to the roof of the house in the mud was also a form of protest by the way it was treated, he said. The detention took place at dawn last Wednesday, the 11th, between 3 am and 4 am, with the argument that Wong Wai Man would maintain an illegal Mahjong business. It was then that he was detained for 48 hours in a squad in the mud, and was then transferred to the Public Prosecution Service (MP) to continue to make statements. After this process, he was notified to present himself with CCAC, having signed the requested documents. He was then arrested again for another 48 hours and transferred again to the MP. When, already on the street, he was again informed that he would have to return to CCAC to sign more documents, decided to escape and take refuge on the roof.

item.title: Breast Cancer | Research of one does “revolutionary discovery”
item.description:
A study by a team led by two professors at the University of Macao seeks answers to combat breast cancer. Academics concluded that cancer cells spread mainly through the lymphatic system, not by the bloodstream
“The lymphatic system is the main route for breast cancer dissemination and metastasis, revealed by tracking unique cell lineage” is a scientific article that seeks to increase knowledge that allows you to find solutions to the disease. The work was developed by a research team led by the full professor Chuxia Deng and assistant professor Miao Kai at the University of Macao Faculty of Health Sciences (one) and, according to a note from UM, is a “revolutionary discovery in the study of cancer metastases”. Thus, and for the first time, “a qualitative and quantitative analysis of breast cancer metastases was made, and was applied by scientists“ a barcode system based on an unique cell lineage tracking approach ”called Celltag. With this method, results were obtained that reveal that "cancer cells spread mainly through the lymphatic system, not by the bloodstream." In addition, he points out one, “research also found that interaction between tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment (TME) determines the metastatic potential of cancer cells”, ie whether or not they may easily reproduce. In this sense, “the study systematically demonstrates the pathways of tumor metastases and opens new ways for the development of cancer treatment strategies”, is described. The article was published in the magazine “Molecular Cancer” and is the result of an investigation by a vast team, consisting of Kai Miao, Aiping Zhang, Xiaodan Yang, Yipeng Zhang, Anqi Lin, Lijian Wang, Xin Zhang, Heng Sun, Jun Xu, Yuzhao Feng, Fangyuan Shao, Sen Guo, Zhihui Weng, Peng Luo, Xiaoling Xu and Ch -xia Deng. Highlight for the collaboration of scientists from other higher education institutions in the region, such as Aiping Zhang, Hong Kong-Shenzhen Hospital University, and Jingyao Zhang and Shuai Gao, linked to China Agricultural University in Beijing. In turn, Dong Wang and Xiao-Yang Zhao are linked to Southern Medical University's School of Basic Medical Sciences in Guangzhou. Microenvironment is an important factor One explains, in the same statement, that the study in question “provides empirical evidence for route preference in cancer metastasis”, demonstrating that tumor cells are “pre-programmed” with “intrinsic information that determine their metastatic potential”, and these cells “adapt dynamically their genetic expression based on the target organs”. Thus, "these findings establish the foundations for the development of therapies directed to lymphatic metastasis, such as inhibition of cytokine signaling or interruption of communication between tumor and stroma to suppress metastasis." In the investigation, the “single cell RNA sequencing technology” was used, which allowed the team to “discover that genetically identical tumor cells exhibit profiles of specific genetic expression of the organ”, so the microenvironment proves to be “fundamental in the formation of tumor cell behavior”. "For example, pulmonary metastatic cells positively regulate oxidative stress -related genes, while hepatic metastatic cells activate metabolic regulatory pathways," is referred to. The danger of metastases One points out that, in cancer diseases, metastases are the main cause of death. However, to date, "the mechanisms that govern the selection of the route" of these same metastases remained "obscure." “Using Celltag technology, the research team traced the spread of breast cancer cells on mice models,” discovered that “less than 3 percent of cancer cells spread throughout the bloodstream, while more than 80 percent metasta through the lymphatic system for distant organs such as lungs and liver”. Thus, "further analysis has shown that lymph spread cells have distinct genetic expression patterns and communicate closely with stromal cells, such as endothelial fibroblasts and cells in the microenvironment, forming an adaptive" seed-solo "mechanism." Looking at the study, the authors explain that cancer metastasis “is a process in which the tumor cells of the primary tumor invade the basal membrane of the blood or lymphatic vessels (intravasation), travel the blood or lymphatic system and colonize distant organs and tissues to continue their development”. Several studies point to the fact that metastases are responsible for 70 to 90 percent of cancer -related mortality, and “the dissemination of tumor cells in the vasculature and lymphatic vessels occurs simultaneously in the vast majority of cancers”. Blood roads In the discussion of the results, the study authors say that, in general terms, “tumor cells metastatize mainly through blood circulation and lymphatic system”, and until the publication of this work had been performed “numerous studies to distinguish the role of both systems in the various phases of cancer metastasis”, without knowing “which way’ for metastasis ”. It is referred to in the article, citing other studies that “cancer cells enter the bloodstream through intravasation to become CTCs [Circulating Tumor Cells-Tumor Cells in circulation], having revealed highly correlated with the survival results of breast cancer patients”. The authors also explain that “the lymphatic system is considered critical for metastasis” because “melanoma cells with experience in the lymphatic system were more resistant to ironPtosis and formed more metastases”, and in cases of “cancer tumor resection, cancer cells can further disseminate the lymphatic ganglia for blood vessels and form tumors and forming tumors metastatic in the lungs ”. To date, “although metastatic dissemination was viable by both ways, the relative importance of each process for a certain type of cancer and the target organ was unknown due to the lack of adequate quantitative tools”, something to which this study, using the celltag system, intended to respond. Thus, “we demonstrate that most lung and liver metastatic cells can be detected in the lymphatic system rather than CTCs [circulation tumor cells] derived from the blood, indicating that lymphatic vessels can be the favorite way for tumor cell metastasis, at least in breast cancer”. The authors promise not to stop here in the discovery of the course made by the metastasis of carcinogenic cells, having already performed "preliminary tests" with some cells in order to find out the possibility of "drastic" reduction of tumor cells disseminated by lymphatic. "We will continue to work on this to deepen the lymphatic dissemination mechanism and explore therapeutic interruptions in our future efforts," he is mentioned.

item.title: Elections | Caeal prevents information photographs that the law obliges to disclose
item.description:
Seng Ioi Man estimated that the final lists of the September 14 elections can be revealed between July 18 and July 31. Candidates are currently being evaluated by the State Security Defense Commission, which has exclusion powers
Although the electoral law requires postering in the public place of candidates for the elections of September 14, to be consulted by the population, the Commission of Electoral Affairs of the Legislative Assembly (Caeal) prohibited that information photographs are taken. The decision was justified by the chairman of the committee, Judge Seng Ioi Man, with the desire to prevent personal data from ending on the internet. According to the defined in the electoral law, after the candidacies are presented, Caeal has to affix the information at its headquarters. Part of this information includes the “complete identification of candidates and representatives”, composed of the name, date of birth, profession, naturalness, habitual residence, postal address and resident identity ticket number. However, and although the information is public, residents cannot take photographs of the affixed leaves. Speaking to journalists, Seng Ioi Man explained the option with the fact that Caeal intends to protect the personal data of candidates. "According to the electoral law, it is necessary to present the identity of the representatives and the candidates. It is necessary to affix all the information. But Caeal found that this information contains many personal data, and given the protection of the personal data of these individuals to CAEAL decided not to take photos," said Seng Ioi Man yesterday. Notices without penalties When Caeal was asked about the article of the law that allows to prevent photographs of public documents, it avoided specifying an article and asked journalists to consult the law. "You, if you need to read the law, can consult the law, because there are very detailed provisions," replied the president of Caeal. With the posting of the lists, warnings emerge to warn that people who disclose published data risk taking legal responsibilities and cannot take photographs. Nar away with the warnings is indicated the penalty corresponding to the disclosure of the information or taking photographs. “The law requires very complete, very detailed information, until the person's BIR number is disclosed, as well as the date of birth, […] after a prudent weighting, it was necessary to publish everything […] but we did not find it prudent to take photographs to safeguard the data of the lists in the lists. It didn't consider it prudent, ”he added. Evaluation lists Currently the lists presented are provisional and given that there were no complaints in the face of the information published by CAEAL about the members of the lists, the applications went to the State Security Defense Commission. The Commission makes the political assessment on the loyalty of candidates for MSAR. The opinion issued is binding to Caeal, and does not allow the appeal of the State Security Defense Commission. Given the procedural procedures of the elections, Seng Ioi Man explained that the decision of the committee should be known as late until July 15. As a result, at best the definitive lists will be confirmed on July 18. However, if there is an appeal for Caeal's decisions, for reasons other than those related to the decisions of the State Security Defense Commission, the disclosure of the final list can only take place on July 31.
